summary: This is the Office of the Inspector General's (OIG) official draft report on the Federal Bureau of Prisons' (BOP) care, custody, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It contains eight recommendations for BOP policy changes following Epstein's death, along with the BOP's responses and the OIG's analysis of those responses.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate whose death while in BOP custody at MCC New York prompted this OIG investigation and report. The report details failures in his supervision.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein in BOP Custody
events.description: The event that triggered the OIG investigation. The report references failures in BOP procedures that contributed to the circumstances surrounding his death.

events.title: Issuance of OIG Draft Report
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General issues its draft report containing findings and eight recommendations to the BOP regarding its care of Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York)
keyFacts: The OIG report states that BOP employees failed to ensure Jeffrey Epstein continuously had a cellmate, despite Psychology Department personnel determining he needed one.
The BOP concurred with all eight OIG recommendations aimed at improving inmate supervision, suicide watch procedures, staffing, and security systems.
The report indicates that the issues leading to Epstein's death were due to employees failing to adhere to duties, not staffing shortages.
The OIG analysis found the BOP's response to Recommendation 2 (ensuring high-risk inmates keep a cellmate) was 'not fully responsive' and required further action.
The BOP has updated its processes related to suicide watch and psychological observation since Epstein's death, implementing a more individualized approach.
